awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Hospitals' Choices and Environmental Pressures
awd_abstract_narration:
Brian Gran
Cory E. Cronin
Case Western Reserve University

This research will study the ways in which environmental pressures affect the choices hospitals make regarding community benefit and business-like practices. Hospitals are important social institutions that play multiple societal roles and inevitably respond to pressures exerted upon them by policy changes, societal expectations, and fiscal realities. Previous research documents the long history of hospitals as centerpieces of their communities, but in recent years, much attention has been paid to efforts of cost control and revenue production and the resulting shift to a more corporate culture within health care organizations. New regulations by the IRS and the passage of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA), however, have brought a renewed focus on the ways in which hospitals contribute to and care for their communities, raising the question of how hospital behaviors have changed in the evolving landscape and what the impacts of these changes might be. 

This study aims to: 1) understand the ways in which hospital environments (including policy implementation and market characteristics) affect hospital choices surrounding community benefit and business-like practices; 2) identify how these factors affect the presence of hospitals in the market; and 3) explore the ways in which market presence and hospital choices regarding practices affect the well-being of their communities. To accomplish these goals, this longitudinal study will use multi-level analysis to examine data collected by the American Hospital Association, the U.S. Census, and the Dartmouth Health Atlas for the years leading up to and immediately after the passage of the ACA. 

This research has three potential broader impacts. First, it will contribute to the scholarship surrounding institutional theory and institutional logics in its consideration of community benefit as a central logic to the institution of health care. Second, it will provide to leaders of health care organizations a demonstration of how organizations across the field are making decisions in these areas and how these decisions affect organizational and community outcomes. Third, policy makers may be better able to create guidelines for hospitals surrounding community benefit based on an understanding of outcomes of these practices.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

 

The first objective of the study is to examine what organizational and environmental factors affect hospitals’ participation levels in community benefit (activities performed by the hospital for the good of the community) and business-like practices. The analysis provides findings helpful in understanding the role of institutional pressures on hospitals and therefore offers insight into the ways in which hospitals interact with societal structures.

· Community benefit participation is increasing across the hospital field, suggesting that community benefit participation is becoming more institutionalized over time.

· Business-like practices and community benefit practices are positively associated, indicating that the values behind these practices may co-exist. This supports the idea of hospitals as complex organizations, with multiple roles and motivations in their social interactions.

· Hospital identity and resources (indicated through structure and size) both play a role in community benefit and business-like practice participation. Nonprofit religious hospitals experience greater odds of high participation in both types of practices, and government and for-profit hospitals experience lower odds. Bed size is positively associated with higher participation. This suggests that organizational identity and resources play important roles in how hospitals behave.

· The state and federal requirements for hospitals to report community benefit were tied to greater levels of community benefit participation and greater odds of increasing participation over time, illustrating the coercive institutional effects of policy.

· Hospitals in markets with higher average community benefit participation levels see greater odds of increasing their own participation. This can be identified as a mimetic effect.

 

The second objective of this study considers how participation in practices reflective of community and corporatization values relates to organizational performance, through closure and market share measures. The most notable findings of this objective are the associations between community benefit practices and stronger organizational performance.

· High orientation toward community benefit planning practices is associated both with lower odds of hospital closure and stronger market share performance. High orientation toward community benefit activity participation also ties to stronger market share.

· Aligning with the logic of community may grant greater legitimacy upon an organization and play a role in securing it within the market.

 

The third objective questions how community benefit activities occurring at the market level relate to community health outcomes. Findings provide a sense of how the efforts of hospitals within a market combine to serve communities within the market.

·  A reasonably high level of community benefit participation exists across markets, further indicating a sense of community benefit practices as an important element within the health care sector.

·  Community health education is associated with lower ambulatory care sensitive condition rates and therefore appears to contribute to improved community health outcomes. This suggests that community health education may be a measure hospitals can take to address health disparities.

BROADER IMPACT
The findings of this research offer a number of potential implications for organization practices. First is that participation in community benefit activities oftentimes serves multiple purposes for a hospital. In addition to satisfying the missions of hospitals, community benefit participation meets regulatory obligations surrounding nonprofit status for tax exemption.
